section.title: Vector Equations

introduction.definition: A matrix A is square if it has the same number of rows as columns. In other words, A is an n \times n matrix, for some n.

section.subsection:
Vectors
The term vector is used widely in mathematics and physics. Here, a vector will simply mean an ordered list of real numbers. In linear algebra, we represent vectors most commonly as a column matrix, a matrix with dimensions 1 \times n, i.e. a matrix with 1 row and n columns. Similarly, a row vector is a m \times 1 matrix, a matrix which has 1 columns and m rows.
First, we will consider vectors with two entries. The set of all vectors with two entries is denoted by \mathbb{R}^2 (read r-squared or simply r-two).
Two vectors in \mathbb{R}^2 are equal if their corresponding entries are equal.
Let \vec{u}, \vec{v} be vectors. Their sum \vec{u} + \vec{v} is the vecotr obtained by adding the corresponding entries of \vec{u} and \vec{v}.
Let \vec{u} be a vector, c \in \mathbb{R}. Then, the scalar multiple of \vec{u} by c, c\vec{u}, is the vector obtained by multiply each entry of \vec{u} by c.
The number c \in \mathbb{R} is called a scalar.
Often, it is simpler to write vectors horizontally rather than vertically, but it is necessary to keep the vertical convention. In this case, we identify a column vector with an ordered tuple of numbers. For example,
\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{is equivalent to} \quad (1,-3)
More generally,
(b_1, \dots, b_n) \quad \text{is equivalent to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ \vdots \\ b_n \end{bmatrix}
Note that (b_1, \dots, b_n) is not a row vector.

subsection.title: Geometry of Vectors in \mathbb{R}^2
subsection.p: Every point in the plane is completely determined by an ordered pair of numbers, so there is a one-to-one correspondence between points in the plane (a,b) and vectors \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}.

subsection.title: Vectors in \mathbb{R}^3
subsection.p: Vectors in \mathbb{R}^3 are 3 \times 1 column matrices, and can be represented geometrically as points in space.

section.subsection:
Vectors in \mathbb{R}^n
More generally, we can consider vectors with n elements.
The set of all ordered n-tuples of n real numbers is denoted by \mathbb{R}^n (read as r-n).
The definitions of equality, sum, and scalar multiple are analogous to that for \mathbb{R}^2 and \mathbb{R}^3,
Vectors \vec{u}, \vec{v} in \mathbb{R}^n are equal if their corresponding entries are equal.
The sum \vec{u} + \vec{v} is obtained by adding entries componentwise.
The scalar multiple c \vec{u} is obtained by multiplying every entry of \vec{u} by c.
The zero vector, denoted by \vec{0}, is the unique vector with entries which are all zeros.
The arithmetic of vectors satisfies many of the familiar laws of arithmetic with numbers.
Properties of vector arithmetic
Let \vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w} \in \mathbb{R}^n be vectors, c, d \in \mathbb{R}. Then,
Addition commutative, \vec{u} + \vec{v} = \vec{v} + \vec{u}.
Addition associative, (\vec{u} + \vec{v}) + \vec{w} = \vec{u} + (\vec{v} + \vec{w}).
Additive identity, \vec{u} + \vec{0} = \vec{0} + \vec{u} = \vec{i}.
Additive inverse, \vec{u} + (-1\vec{u}) = \vec{0}.
Scalar multiplication associative, c(d\vec{u}) = (cd)\vec{u}.
Scalar multiplication distributes over addition, c(\vec{u} + \vec{v}) = c\vec{u} + c\vec{v}.
Vectors distribute over addition, (c + d)\vec{u} + c\vec{u} + d\vec{u}.
For simplicity, the scalar multiple -1\vec{u} is written as -\vec{u}, and is called the additive inverse of \vec{u}. These properties all essentially follow from the corresponding properties of real numbers.

subsection.title: Linear Combinations of Vectors
subsection.definition:
Let \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2, \dots, \vec{v}_n \in \mathbb{R}^n be vectors, a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n \in \mathbb{R} be scalars. Then, the vector \vec{v} given by,
\vec{v} = a_1 \vec{v}_1 + a_2 \vec{v}_2 + \dots + a_n \vec{v}_n = \sum_{i=1}^n a_i \vec{v}_i
is called a linear combination of \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2, \dots, \vec{v}_n \in \mathbb{R}^n with weights a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n.
subsection.example:
Given any collection of vectors, the trivial linear combination is that with all weights being 0, i.e.,
0 \vec{v}_1 + 0 \vec{v}_2 + \dots + 0 \vec{v}_n = \vec{0}

subsection.title: Geometric Interpretation of Span
subsection.p: If \vec{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2. Then, \Span{\vec{v}} is precisely the set of all scalar multiple of \vec{v}. Equivalently, the set of points on the line in \mathbb{R}^2 through \vec{v} and \vec{0}.

If \vec{u}, \vec{v} \in \mathbb{R}^2 are non-zero vector, and \vec{v} is not a multiple of \vec{v}, then \Span{\vec{u}, \vec{v}} makes up the entire plane \mathbb{R}^2. In \mathbb{R}^3, \Span{\vec{u}, \vec{v}} consists of the plane in \mathbb{R}^3 which contains \vec{u}, \vec{v} and \vec{0}.
